awd_titl_txt: A Design Framework for Programmable Manufacturing of Customized Knitted Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
Knitting is the intermeshing of yarns into loops that leads to the creation of fabrics. Fabrics knitted with several different yarns constitute a modern class of advanced engineering materials. Additionally, computer-controlled knitting offers great promise as a digital manufacturing technology because of the ability to make novel materials from multiple yarn types and varying loop patterns. Given the enormous flexibility of modern knitting equipment and the variety of yarn materials currently available, knitted structures can now be viewed as a versatile, programmable, multi-scale and microstructure-based engineering material system that can be designed and manufactured to meet a wide range of functional and mechanical requirements. While the current state of the art in commercial knitting technology is quite capable of designing and manufacturing a variety of materials for consumer clothing, many significant technological gaps exist that prevent knitting from becoming a general process for digital manufacturing. The critical barrier to the production of these versatile material systems is the lack of validated comprehensive design tools and accurate predictive modeling methods. This project will develop an integrated design framework that addresses these barriers in order to enable the programmable manufacturing of customized knitted materials. Developing advanced technologies in this field has the potential to create new, revitalized economic activity in an American industrial sector that has mostly known decline in recent decades. 
 
The project has several technical objectives. They are: a) the creation of a design framework that determines yarn specifications and processing commands given the performance requirements for a knitted material, b) the development of a data-driven algorithm for computing inverse mappings from low-dimensional requirements space into high-dimensional control data space that utilizes efficient nearest-neighbors search and scattered data interpolation techniques to find viable design solutions for knitted materials, c) the definition of an objective function capable of determining if knitting design requirements have been fulfilled, d) the utilization of information pathways that allow for an inverse-forward simulate-manufacture-evaluate-validate feedback loop in the design process, and e) the integration of design/simulation processes with the production, testing and evaluation of actual materials to provide an accelerated, programmable manufacturing capability for novel, customized knitted materials.

por.por_cntn:
Knitting involves the formation of yarn loops that are intertwined with each other to create whole fabrics. Knitted fabrics constitute a modern class of advanced engineering materials that have tremendous potential impact within a wide variety of applications.  Computer-controlled knitting offers great promise as an advanced additive manufacturing technology, because of its ability to make novel materials from multiple yarn types and varying loop patterns. Many significant technological gaps exist that prevent knitting from becoming a general process for digital manufacturing. The critical barrier to the production of these versatile material systems is the lack of validated design and predictive modeling methods.

This project's goal was to advance the capabilities, applicability and impact of computer-controlled knitting by developing the modeling and design technologies and know-how needed for the automated manufacturing of knitted materials.  The project had several components, 1) the creation of a design framework that determines yarn specifications and processing commands given the performance requirements for a knitted material, 2) the development of advanced technologies for modeling and simulating knitted materials, and 3) the integration of design/simulation processes with the production, testing and evaluation of actual materials to provide an accelerated, programmable manufacturing capability for novel, customized knitted materials.

The majority of our efforts were focused on the second component, the development of computational technologies capable of modeling and simulating knitted materials.  This effort was broken down even further into three tasks, simulating knits using Finite Element Modeling (FEM), developing a technique for determining and representing the topology of the yarns (i.e. how the yarns are connected to each other) in a knitted fabric, and exploring the mathematics of minimal surfaces to model and simulate knitted materials. The first task is important for predicting the shape and mechanical properties of a knitted material.  Yarn topology is needed when predicting how water, heat or electricity might flow through a knitted fabric.  The final task involved conducting basic research that should lead to a much more efficient and robust approach to the modeling and simulation of knitted materials.  It should be noted that modeling and simulation are an important part of computational design, which allows one to evaluate a design on a computer before the item/material is actually manufactured. Thus making it possible to test out many design ideas virtually, saving time and money during the manufacturing process.

Results from our modeling efforts are included.              

The top left figure presents the results from one of our FEM simulations of an all-knit swatch of knitted fabric.  It is color-coded to highlight the out-of-plane deformation of the fabric, a behavior that would not be seen in conventional continuous materials.

The figure on the top right presents an automatically generated graph that represents the topology (i.e. connectivity) of the yarn in a fabric consisting of knit, transfer, miss and tuck stitches.

The middle figures present a model of the yarns in a rib fabric. The geometry and topology of the yarn model are produced by fitting the yarn to a helicoid scaffold, as seen on the left side of the figure.

The bottom figure presents the physical prototype that was used to confirm that helicoid scaffolds can be used to define the yarns in a knitted fabric.

The grant supported the studies of five female graduate students, who investigated textile-related science and technologies while pursuing advances degrees in mechanical engineering, computer science, material science and design. Four undergraduate students were also involved in the project, as well as a local high school teacher.

The faculty team that led this NSF project contributed to the establishment of a National Institute for Manufacturing Innovation, headquartered at MIT. Called AFFOA (Advanced Functional Fabrics of America), the institute was formed to enable a manufacturing-based revolution by transforming traditional fibers, yarns, and fabrics into highly sophisticated, integrated and networked devices and systems. Under the auspices of AFFOA and with support from the state of Pennsylvania and Drexel University, the team also established a Fabric Discovery Center at Drexel (PA FDC), a collaborative partnership between academia, government, and industry created to provide a new economy based on advanced textile-related innovations, collaborations, and connections at educational and industrial levels.

This NSF-funded project will have lasting impact through a number of avenues. 1) The knowledge discovered and technologies invented have advanced the state-of-the-art for knitted material modeling, simulation and design.   We and others will build upon these advancements to produce future technical innovations. 2) The students trained during the project have now moved onto industrial jobs or are pursuing additional education opportunities here in the United States. They are contributing to the economic well-being of our nation. 3) The NSF support of the project's leadership team also contributed to the establishment of major university-industry-government centers that continue to foster innovation, expand the manufacturing workforce and enhance industrial capacity in textile-related fields.
